div.p:
XXVIII 286
It is a good means of arresting
the attention and conveying
important facts to the minds
25 of these people

When erecting our sheds
6 inat the village Manenko fell
upon our friends from
Masiko in a way that
left no doubt on our
minds but that ^ she is a most
accomplished scold - Masiko
had on a former occasion
sent to Samoana for a cloth --
a common way of keeping up
intercourse -- and after recievingreceiving
it sent it back because it had
the appearance of having had
witchcraft medicine on it;,
This was a grave offence, and
now Manenko had an
excuse for venting her spleen, --
for in the ambassadors having
called at her villages, and
slept in one of the huts ^ without leave - If
her family was to be suspected
of dealing in evil charms
why were Masiko's people
not to be suspected of
having such in her hut -
She advanced and receded in
true oratorical style, - belabouring
her own servants as well
for allowing the offence,
and, as usual in more civilized
feminine lectures, leaned over
287
over the objects of her ire, and
screamed forth all their faults
26 and failings ever since they were
born, and her despair of ever
seeing them becoming better untilluntil
they were hanged, ("killed by
alligators - ") Masiko's people
followed the silent plan of
recievingreceiving this torrent of abuse,
and as nietherneither we nor they
had any thing to eat we parted
next morning - In reference to Masiko
to selling
slaves to
the Mambari Theythey promised
to explain the relationship which
exists between even the most
abject of his people to our
common Father, and that
no more kidnapping should
be allowed as he ought
to give that peace and
security to the smaller
tribes on his Eastern borders,
which he so much desired
to obtain himself from the
Makololo, And we promised
to return through his town
when we came back from
the sea coast -

Manenko gave us some
Manioc roots in the morning
and had determined to carry
our baggage to her uncle's
Kabompo or Shinté -; We
had a sample of what she
could do with her tongue
288
and neither my men nor myself
had much inclination to encounter
a scolding from this black Mrs Caudle,
27 so we made ready the packages,
but she said she the men
whom she had ordered for
the service had not yet
come, - They would arrive
tomorrow - Being on low
and dis-agreabledisagreeable diet we I
felt annoyed at this further
delay, & ordered the packages
to be put into the canoes, -
to and proceed up the river
without her people; - But
Manen̄ko was not to be
circumvented in that way;
She came forward ^ with her people and said
her uncle would be angry
if she did not carry forward
the tusks and goods of Sekeletu, -
seized the luggage and added
she would carry it in spite
of me - My men succumbed
to this petticoat government
sooner than I did so, I had
leaving me no power, - and being unwilling
to encounter her tongue
I was moving off to the
canoes; - but she gave me
such a kindly explanation,
and with her hand on
my shoulder put on a motherly
look -, saying, now my little man
just do as the rest have done
289
myMy feelings of annoyance
vanished, and I went - out
28 to try and get some fmeat

The only game to be found
in these parts is the Zebra
Kualata, or Tahetsi (Aigoceros
equina) Kama (Bubalus
caama) buffaloes, - and
the small antelope - (Philantomba)

The animals Theycan be seen only by
following on their trail for
many ^ miles; We Urged on by hunger
we followed that of some
Zebras during the greater part
of the day, - When within
fifty yards of them ain a
dense thicket, I made sure
of one, but to my infinite
disgust the gun missed fire
and off they bounded, - The
climate is so very damp, from
daily heavy rains, that
every thing becomes loaded
with moisture, and the
powder in the gun nipples
cannot be kept dry
It is curious to mark the
intelligence of the game in
different parts, - In pdistricts
where they are much
annoyed by fire arms, - They
keep out on the most
open spots of country they can
find - in order to have
290
a widely extended range of vision,
and a man arrmed is carefully
shunned - From the frequency
29 with which I have been allowed
to approach nearer without
than with a gun I believe
they know the difference
of safety and danger in the
two cases - But here, where
they are killed by the arrows
of the Balonda, - they select
for safety the densest
forest where the arrow
cannot be easily shot - The
difference of sethe selection
of standing spots during
the day may however
partly be owing to the greater
heat of the sun - for here it
is particularly sharp and
piercing by day, - However
accounted for the lifwild
animals here do select
the forests by day, while
those ^ farther in the South generally
shun themse - ^ covers, and on several
occasions I have observed
there was no sun to cause
them to seek for shade

291
Cross 11th January 1854 On starting this morning
Samoana or rather Nyamoana
30 for the ladies are the chiefs
here presented a string of
beads and a shell highly valued
among them as an atonement
for having ^ assisted Manenko as they thought
to vexed me ythe day before
They seemed anxious to avert
any evil which might arise
from my ill will ^ displeasure but having
replied that I never kept up
my anger all night they were
well pleased when I seemed
to see me satisfied - We had to cross a
stream which flows past the
village of Nyamoana in a
canoe - Manenko's doctor
waved some charms over her
and she took
some in her
hand and
on her body ^ before she ventured upon the
water - One of my men
spoke rather loudly when
near the Doctorsdoctor's basket of
medicines - The doctor reproved
him and spoke always in
a whisper himself glancing
back to the basket as if
afraid of being heard by something
therein - So much superstition
is quite unknown in the
South and is mentioned here
to shewshow the difference in the
feelings of this new people &
and the comparative want of
feeling on these points among Caffres & Bechuanas

292
Manenko was accompanied
by her husband and drummer
31 The latter continued to thump most
vigorously untilluntil a heavy Scotch
mist sets in and compelled
him to desist - Her husband
used various incantations
and vociferations to drive
the rain away but on it poured
incessantly, and on our
Amazon went in the very
lightest marching order at
a pace that few of the men
could keep up with her
I being on ox back could
went kept pretty close to our
leader and asked her why
she did not clothe herself
during the rain and learned
that it is not considered proper
for a chief to appear effeminate
He or she must always wear
the appearance of robust youth
& little else and bear the
vis-cissitudesvicissitudes without wincing
My men in admiration
of her pedestrian powers
every mow & then remarked
"Manenko is a soldier" and
thoroughly wet & cold we were
all glad when she proposed
to prepare our nightsnight's lodgings
on the banks of a stream

293
The country through which
32 we were passing was ^ athe same succession
of forest and open lawns
as was formerly mentioned - The
forest trees were nearly all
evergreens and the open of good
though not very gigantic
size - The lawns were
covered with grass which
in thickness of crop looked
like ordinary by English
hay - We passed two small
Hamletshamlets surrounded by
gardens of maize and
Manioc and near these
we observed for the first
time an ugly idol common
in Londa of an animal
resembling an alligator
made of clay - The structure
is of grass pl palastered over
with soft clay - Two cowrie
shells form the eyes &
a numbers of ththe bristles from
the tail of an elephant are
are inserted inabout the neck
It is called a lion though
if one were not told he
would conclude it to be
an alligator - It stood
in a shed and they ^ the Balonda ^ pray &
beat drums before them it
all night in cases of
sickness -

294
Some of the men of ManenkosManenko's
33 train had shields made of reeds
neatly woven into a square ofabout
five feet long & three broad
With these and short broad
swords and sheaves of iron
headed arrows they appeared
rather ferocious characters
But the constant habit of
wearing arms is probably
only a substitute for the
courage they do not possesss
We always deposited our
fire arms and spears outside
a village before entering it
while the Balonda on
visiting us at our encampment
always come fully armed
untilluntil we ordered them either
to lay down their weapons
or be off

Next day we passed
through a piece of dense forest
so dense no one could have
penetrated it without an axe
It was flooded not by the river
but by the continued rains
which passed down every
day and kept those who
had clothing constantly wet
I observed ^ Inin this piece of forest I
noticed what a very strong
smell of sulphuretted hydrogen
This I had observed repeatedly
in other parts before - I had
295
attacks of fever of the intermittent
34 type again and again in
consequence of repeated
drenchings in these unhealthy
part

On the ^ 11th & 12th we were detained
by long incessant rains so
heavy I never saw the
like in the south - I had
a little tapioca & a small quantity
of Libonta meal which I
reserved for
worse times : the patience
of my men in hunger
was admirable - The actual
want is never so painful
as the thought of getting nothing
in front - We thought the
people of some large hamlets
near us very niggardly
and very independantindependent
of their chiefs for they
gave us ^ & Manenko nothing though
they had large fields of
maize in an eatable state
around them - When she
went and kindly begged some
for me they gave her
five cobs only - They were
subjects of her uncle
and had they been Makololo
would have been lavish
in their gifts to the nephew
of their chief, I suspect
they are dependants of some
296
of some of ShintesShinte's principal
35 men and have no power
to part with the maize of
their masters -

Robinson Each house of these
hamlets has a palisade of
thick stakes around it
and the door is made to
resemble the rest of the
stocadestockade - They are never
seen open - when the owner
wishes to ^ enters he removes a stake
or two - squeezes his body
in then plants them again
in their places so that
an enemy coming in
the night would find it
difficult to discover
the place of ingress - These
palisades seem to indicate
a sense of insecurity in
regard to their fellow men
for there are no wild beasts
to disturb them - the bows
and arrows arehave been
nearly as efficaceousefficacious
in clearing the country
here as guns have in
the country farther South
This wasis a disappointment
to us for we expected a
continuance of the abundance
of game in the North which
we found when we first
came up to the confluence of
297
the Leeba and Leeambye

36 A species of RododendronRhododendron
tree closely resembling the
the Le silver tree of the Cape
(Leucodendron Argenteum) grows
in abundance in the parts
through which we have
travelled since leaving Samoana
As it grows at a height
of between 2000 & 3000 feet
above the level of the
sea on Table Mountain
at the Cape - and again
on the Northern slope
of the CashanMagaliesberg Mountains
and here, at similar heights
it may be considered
as ^ affording an approximation
to the ^ altitudes barometrical heights -
The rapid flow of the Leeambye
which I once considered
evidence of much elevation
of the country from which
it flows comes, I now
consider to be not certai so
sure a guide as the botanical
range noticed above - The
test by the boiling point
of water proves the botanical
evidence to be so far
correct -

298
The forest became more
dense as we went North - We
37 travelled much more in the
deep gloom of the forest than
in open sunlight - No passage
existed on either side of the
narrow path made by the
axe - Large climbing plants
entwining themselves around
the trunks and branches
of gigantic trees like boa
constrictors and suchthey often
do constrict the trees inby
which they rose and killing
them stand erect themselves
The bark of a fine tree
found in abundance here
and called "Motuia" is used
by the Barotse for making
fish lines and nets
and the Molompi so well
adptedadapted for paddles by its
lightness and flexibiltyflexibility
was abundant - Others were
quite new to my companions
but many of them ran
up to a height of fifty feet
of one thickness and
without branches

In these forests we
first encountered ^ the artificial
bee hives so commonly
met with all the ^ way from this
to Angola - They consist
299
of the about five feet of the
38 bark of a tree fifteen or
eighteen inches in diameter
OneTwo Incisionsincisions are made right
round the tree at points five
feet apart from each other
Then one longitudinal slipt
from one slit ^ of these to the other
The workman then lifts
up the bark on each side of
this slit and detaches it from
the trunk taking care not
to break it untilluntil the whole
comes from the tree - The
elasticity of the bark makes
it assume the form it had
before - The slit is sewed
or pegged ^ up with wooden pins
and ends made of coiled
grass rope inserted having
a hole for the ingress of
the bees ^ in the centre and the hive is
complete - They are placed
on high trees in a horizontal
position in different parts
of the forest - In this way
all the wax
exported
from BenguellaBenguela
and LoandoLuanda
is collected
It is all the
produce of
free labour A piece of
medicine is tied round
the trunk of the trees and
proves sufficient protection
against thevieves - They seldom
rob each other for all
believe that certain medicines
can inflict disease & death
and though they consider
that these are only known
300
to a few they act on the principle
39 that it is best to let them
all alone - The gloom of
these forests strengthens the
superstitious feelings of the
people - In other parts where
they ^ the people are not subjected
to this influence I have heard
the chiefs issue proclamations
to the effect that real witchraftwitchcraft
medicines had been placed
at certain gardens from which
produce had been stolen on - The
thieves having risked the
power of the ordinary medcharms
previously placed there

This being the rainy season
great quantities of Mushrooms
were met with and were
eagerly devoured by my
companions - The edible
variety is always found
growing out of anthills
and attains the diameter
of the crown of onesone's hat
They are quite white and
very good wheneven when
eaten raw - They areoccupy
an extensive region of
the Interior - others arenot
edible are of a brilliant
red and other of the same
light blue as the paper used
by apothecaries to put up their medicines

301
Bristow There was considerable
pleasure in spite of rain & fever
40 in this new scenery - The
deep gloom contrasted strongly
with the shadeless glare - of
the Kalahari to which I had
been & left an indelible
impression on my memory
Though drenched day by day
forat at this time and for
months afterwards it was
long before I could believe
that we were getting too
much of a good thing,
Nor could I look at the water
being thrown away without
a slight quick impression
flitting across the mind
that we were guilty of
waste - Every now & then
we emerged from the deep
gloom into a pretty little
valley having a damp
portion in the middle which
though now filled with
water at other times contains
moisture enough for
wells only - These wells
have shades put over them
in the form of little huts

We crossed a little
never failing stream in
canoes which passes by
the name Lefuje or the rapid
302
It comes from a good high
mountain which we & called
41 Monakadzi (the woman) which
gladdened our eyes as it
rose to our sight about
twenty or thirty miles to the
East of our course - It is
of an oblong shape and
seemed at least a thousan
800 feet above the plains
below - The Lefuje coming
from it probably derives
its name from the rapid
descent of the short course
it has to flow from the
Monakadzi to the Leeba -

The numbers of little
villages seemed about equal
to the number of valleys
at some we stopped and rested
the people becoming more
liberal as we advanced - Oth^eers
we found emptydeserted a sudden
panic having seized the
in habitants though the drum
of Manenko was kept
beaten ^ going pretty constantly in
order to give notice
of the approach of great
people - When we had decided
to remain for the night at any
village the inhabitants lent
us their roofs of their huts
303
which in form resemble a
Chinaman's hat and can
42 be taken off the walls at
pleasure - They lifted them
off and brought them to the
spot we had selected as our
lodging and when my men
propedpropped them up with stakes
they were then safely housed
for the night - Every one
who comes to salute either
Manenko or us smears
rubs ^ the upper part of the arms
and chest with ashes - Those
who wish to shewshow profounder
reverence put some also
on the face - We found also
that every village had its
idols near it This is the
case all through the country
of the Balonda so that
when we came to an
idol in the woods we
always knew that we
were within a quarter
of an hour of human
habitations - One idovery
ugly idol we passed had
two loops restinged on a
horizontal beam placed on
two upright posts - This
beam was furnished with
two loops of cord as of a
chain to suspend offerings
before it - On remarking
304
to our own my companions
that these idols had ears
but they heard not &c - I learned
that the ^ Balonda and Barotse even believe
that divination may be
43 performed by means of these
blocks of wood & clay
and though the wood itself
could not hear the owners
had medicines by which
they could be made to hear
and give responses,
so that if an enemy were
approaching they would
have full information
Manenko having brought
us to a stand on account
of slight indisposition and
desire to send forward
notice of our approach
to her uncle - I asked
if Shinte had idols who
could tell him everything
why it was necessary
to send forward information
of our movements - "She
did it only" was they reply -
It is seldom of much use
to shewshow one who worships
idols the folly of idolatry
without giving something
else instead - They do not love
them - They fear them and
betake themselves to their idols
only when in perplexity & danger

305
Chester Whilst delayed among the Balonda
villages a little to the South of
the town of Shinte by ManenkosManenko's
management we were well
44 supplied by the villagers
with sweet potatoes - and
green maize - SambanziaSambanza went
to his mothersmother's village for
supplies of other food and
as I was labouring under
fever I did not find it
difficult to exercise patience
with her whims - but it being
Saturday I thought we might
as well go on to the town
for Sunday (15th) "No, her
messenger must return
from her uncle first - " Being
sure that the answer of the
uncle would be favourable
we might I thought we might
go on at once and not
lose two days in the same
spot - "No it is out custom"
and everything else I could urge
was answered in the genuine
pertinaceouspertinacious lady style - She
ground some meal for me
with her own hands and
when she brought it told me
she had actually gone to a
village and begged corn for
the purpose, she said this with
an air as if the inference must
be drawn by even a stupid white man
306
"I know how to manage, dontdon't I?"
It was refreshing to get food which
could be eaten without producing
the effectunpleasant described by Revd
John Newton of St Mary's
Woolnoth -
London when obliged
to eat the same roots while
a slave in the West Indies
SThe day (Saturday 14th) for a wonder
45 was fair and the sun
shone so as to allow us to
dry our clothing and other
goods many of which
were mouldy and rotten
from the long continued
damp - The guns rusted
in spite of being oiled
every evening

During the night we
were all awakened by a
terrific shriek from one
of Manenko's ladies - She
piped out so loud and
long we all imagined she
had been seized by a lion
and my men all seiz snatched
up their arms which they
always place so as to
be ready at a moment's
notice and ran to the rescue
but we found the alarm
had been caused by one
of the oxen thrusting his
head into her hut and
smelling at her she had put
307
her hand on his cold wet nose
and thought it all over with
her -

On Sunday afternoon
messengers arrived from
Shinte expressionexpressing his approbation
46 of the objects we have in
view in our journey
through his country and
that he was glad of the
prospect of a way being
opened up which white
man might visit him
and allow him to purchase
ornaments at pleasure
Manenko now
threatened in
sport to go on
and I cwould now see that the
what seemed to me the
dilly dallying way of ^ this lady Manenko
was the proper mode
of making acquaintance
with the Balonda and
much of the favour with
which I was afterwards
recievedreceived in different places
was owing to my sending
forward messengers to
to state the object of coming
before entering the town
When we came in sight
of a village we sat down
under the shade of a tree
and sent forward a man
to give notice of who we
were and what were our
objects - The headman of
308
of the village then sent out
his principal men as shinteShinte
now did to bid us welcome
and shewsshows a tree under
which we might sleep -
47 Before I had profited by the
rather tedious teaching of
Manenko I sometimes entered
a village and created unintention-
-al alarm - The villagers
201 would continue to [look
upon [us with suspicion
as long ⎣as we remained
Shinte sent us two large
baskets of manioc and
six dried fishes - ^ His men They had
on the skins of a monkey
called Poluma in their tongue
which is of a jet black
colour except the long mane
which is pure white - It is
said to be found in the
North - or country of Matiamvo
11 the paramount chief of all
the Balonda - We learned
from them that that they are
in the habit of praying
to their idols in when
unsuccessful in killing
game or in any other
enterprise - They behaved
with reverence at our
religious services - This
will appear important
309
if the reader remembers
the almost total want of
prayer and reverence we
encountered in the South -

48
Our friends informed
us that Shinte would be highly
honoured by the presence
of three white men in his
town at once - Two others
had sent forward notice
of their appraoch from
another quarter (the West)
Could this be Barth or Krapf
How pleasant to meet
with Europeans in such
an out of the way region
The rush of thoughts made
me almost forget my fever
"Are Have they theof the same colour
as I am - ?" -- "Yes exactly so"
"And Havehave they the same
hair?" -- "Is that hair? we
thought it was a wig - "? We
never saw the like before"
This white man must be of
the sort that lives outin the
sea" My men took the hint
from this and always
sounded my praises after-
wards as a true specimen
of the variety of white men
who live in the Sea - "Look
at his hair it is made quite
straight by the ^ sea water"
